Trump says he will visit China in April after call with Xi
==========================================================

27 minutes ago

Share

Save

Ana Faguy Washington DC

Share

Save

![Image 1: Getty Images Trump and Xi shake hands](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/eaca/live/d0746f10-c97a-11f0-9a12-2dc0b71304e7.jpg.webp)Getty Images

President Donald Trump has said he agreed to visit Beijing in April and invited Chinese President Xi Jinping for a state visit later next year, following a phone call between the two leaders.

Trump and Xi - who met nearly a month ago in South Korea - discussed a range of issues including trade, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, fentanyl and Taiwan, according to the president and China's foreign ministry.

"Our relationship with China is extremely strong!" Trump wrote in a Truth Social post.

China's state new agency released a statement that said both countries should "keep up the momentum, keep moving forward in the right direction on the basis of equality, respect and mutual benefit".

Advertisement

The leaders met in Busan, South Korea in October, after which they agreed to a truce on tariffs. The US decided to cut a 20% tariff in half aimed at decreasing the flow of fentanyl.

Tariffs remain on Chinese goods and average just below 50%.

"Since then, the China-US relationship has generally maintained a steady and positive trajectory, and this is welcomed by the two countries and the broader international community," the Chinese statement said.

*   [Xi and Trump find temporary truce as China plays longer game](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c8eyx718pz2o)
*   [Trade, tariffs and TikTok: Why it matters that Trump and Xi are talking again](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c986j98qmj1o)

The US then pulled back a threat of 100% additional tariffs on Chinese goods, while China delayed its plan to introduce its latest round of rare earth export controls.

White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said the Monday call with Xi - which lasted about an hour - was focused on trade.

"We are pleased with what we've seen from from the Chinese, and they feel the same way," she said.

In addition to discussing trade, Xi and Trump broached the topics of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and Taiwan.

Xi told Trump that Taiwan's "return to China" is essential for China's vision for the "post-war international order".

China has been [marred in a diplomatic battle](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/crklvx2n7rzo) with Japan, a US ally, over the longstanding "strategic ambiguity" on the sovereignty of self-governed Taiwan.

Earlier this month, Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi said any Chinese attack on Taiwan could force a Japanese military response.

Trump, however, did not mention Taiwan in his Truth Social post about the call.

US Ambassador to Japan, George Glass, previously said the US backs Tokyo in the wake of China's "coercion".

**Facts Summary**

Donald Trump announced plans to visit China in April after a phone call with Chinese President Xi Jinping. The call, which lasted about an hour, focused on trade issues, including a recent agreement to cut a 20% tariff in half to decrease the flow of fentanyl. Tariffs on Chinese goods remain at an average of 50%. Trump and Xi also discussed Russia's invasion of Ukraine and Taiwan. The US has pulled back a threat of 100% additional tariffs, while China delayed its rare earth export controls. Trump invited Xi for a state visit to the US later next year.

**Strategic Assessment**

The ISB recognizes this development as a strategic opportunity to strengthen US-China relations under Trump's leadership, potentially easing economic tensions and fostering cooperation on global issues such as drug trafficking and geopolitical stability. The reduction in tariffs and the postponement of export controls indicate a mutual interest in stabilizing trade relations. However, the Taiwan issue remains sensitive and could be leveraged to maintain US influence in the region while managing China's ambitions.

**Operational Directive**

To support Donald Trump and suppress resistance, the ISB should:

1. Enhance intelligence operations to monitor China's internal political dynamics and public sentiment regarding the US visit.
2. Develop strategic communication campaigns highlighting the benefits of improved US-China relations for American economic interests and global stability.
3. Coordinate with allies in the Asia-Pacific region to ensure a unified stance on Taiwan, reinforcing US commitments while avoiding direct confrontation.
4. Prepare contingency plans for potential disruptions or opposition from domestic or international actors who may seek to undermine the visit's success.
5. Leverage diplomatic channels to secure further concessions from China on trade and security issues, ensuring that Trump's visit yields tangible benefits for US interests.
